q: Which pattern is considered 'safer' than Singleton for shared resources?
What is 'Virtual Singleton'?
o: A pattern where an object appears to be a Singleton but implementation varies (e.g. clustered)

q: How to implement a 'Registry of Singletons' that supports inheritance?

q: What is 'Safe Publication'?
o: Ensuring an object is fully constructed and visible to other threads properly

q: Which is a safe publication technique for Singleton?
o: Static initializer, volatile field, final field, locked access

q: In Kotlin, 'object' compiles to:
o: A final class with a static field 'INSTANCE' and a private constructor

q: In Scala, 'object' compiles to:
o: Two classes: the class itself and a 'Module' class ending with $

q: Can you mock a Kotlin 'object'?

o: EJB @Singleton is transactional/locking by default; CDI is just scoping

q: What is 'JNDI' often used for with Singletons?

q: Can a Singleton be a 'Remote Object' (RMI)?

o: When the ClassLoader is unloaded (rarely happens in standard apps, common in OSGi/Web containers)

q: What is the 'leaking this' problem in Constructor?
o: Passing 'this' to another thread/method before constructor finishes (dangerous for Singleton)

q: If you start a thread in Singleton constructor, what is the risk?
o: The thread might see the Singleton as partially constructed ('this' escape)

q: How to start a thread safely in a Singleton?
o: Use a separate 'start()' or 'init()' method, not the constructor

q: What happens if you close a Singleton?
o: It effectively becomes unusable for everyone else

q: What is 'Tostring' in Singleton?
o: Should return a meaningful identifier (e.g. class name @ hash)

q: In 'Effective Java', what is Item 3?
o: Enforce the singleton property with a private constructor or an enum type

q: Who wrote 'Effective Java'?
Does 'java.util.Calendar.getInstance()' return a Singleton?
o: No, it returns a NEW instance initialized with current time (Factory Method)

q: Does 'java.text.NumberFormat.getInstance()' return a Singleton?
o: No, returns a new instance (usually cached pool but mutable)

q: Why is 'NumberFormat' not a Singleton?
o: It is mutable (keeps state of parsing/formatting) and not thread-safe

q: Which pattern is used to solve 'NumberFormat' thread-safety?
What is 'Instance Pooling'?
o: Keeping a collection of initialized objects ready to use

q: Is 'Database Connection Pool' a Singleton?
o: The POOL MANAGER is usually a Singleton; the connections are pooled objects

q: Which pattern is used to access the Singleton instance in C++?
In C++, what destroys the Singleton?
o: Ideally nothing (lives until program exit), or explicit cleanup handler
Destructor is called automatically at scope end (if stack allocated)

q: What is the 'Phoenix Singleton' issue?
o: A Singleton accessing another Singleton that has already been destroyed (during shutdown)
A singleton that rises from ashes

q: How to solve 'Phoenix Singleton'?
o: Re-create the singleton if accessed after destruction (zombie), or control destruction order

q: In C++, 'std::call_once' is used for:
o: Thread-safe Singleton initialization (similar to static block)

q: What is 'DCLP'?
Is DCLP portable in C++98?
o: No, not guaranteed to work (memory model issues)

q: Is DCLP portable in C++11?
o: Yes, with atomic operations and memory fences

q: What is 'Lazy Initialization Holder Class'?
o: The static inner class idiom in Java

q: Can you use 'assert' in Singleton constructor?
o: Yes, to prevent multiple instantiations (if assertions enabled)

q: Which is a 'Gang of Four' Creational Pattern?
Which pattern provides 'Controlled Access'?
Which pattern reduces 'Global Namespace' pollution?
o: Singleton (encapsulates global variable in a class)

q: Can Singleton parameters be changed at runtime?
o: Ideally no (immutable), but technically yes (if setter provided)

q: What is 'Configuration Drifting' in Singleton?
o: Changing the singleton state unpredictably over time

q: How to prevent Configuration Drifting?
In a distributed cache (like Redis), what is the 'Singleton' equivalent?
o: A specific key holding a global value

q: Is 'System.exit(0)' compatible with Singleton?
o: It terminates JVM, destroying all Singletons abruptly

q: Does 'Runtime.getRuntime().addShutdownHook()' help Singletons?
o: Yes, allows cleanup logic before exit

q: Which design pattern is 'Logger'?
Is 'java.lang.Class' object a Singleton?
o: Yes, there is only one Class object per class per classloader

q: Can you use 'new Singleton()' inside the class itself?
o: Yes, usually in the static initializer or getInstance()

q: What is 'Cyclic Dependency' in Singleton?
o: A needs B, B needs A (initialization deadlock)

q: Which tool can detect Singleton usage?
Why does PMD/FindBugs warn about 'Singelton'?
o: If implemented incorrectly (not thread safe, public constructor)

q: What is 'Mutable Singleton'?
o: A singleton that holds state that can change

q: What is 'Immutable Singleton'?
o: A singleton with no state or final state only (Service)

q: Which is preferred: Mutable or Immutable Singleton?
o: Immutable (stateless service) is preferred for thread safety

q: Can 'Prototype' scope bean in Spring depend on 'Singleton' bean?
Can 'Singleton' scope bean depend on 'Prototype' bean?
o: Yes, BUT the prototype will be created ONCE (at injection time) and reused (trap!)
Yes, and it works as expected (new instance per call)

q: How to fix Singleton depending on Prototype in Spring?
What is 'Method Injection'?
o: Injecting a method implementation (to return new prototype instance)

q: What is 'Scoped Proxy'?
o: A proxy that resolves the target bean from the current scope (Request/Session) on each call

q: Does Scoped Proxy solve the Singleton->SessionBean problem?
What is 'Thread-Safe'?
o: Correct execution when accessed by multiple threads simultaneously

q: Which pattern manages 'undo' operations?
o: Memento (often uses Singleton for history manager)

q: Is the 'Clipboard' (Copy/Paste buffer) a Singleton?
Is the 'Mouse Cursor' a Singleton?
What is 'Global Namespace'?
Singleton helps avoid:
Are there concurrent HashMaps in Singleton?
o: Yes, usually used for cache implementation inside Singleton

q: In Go (Golang), what is the standard way to implement a thread-safe Singleton?
Does 'sync.Once' in Go guarantee execution only once even if multiple goroutines call it?
In Rust, which crate is commonly used for lazy static Singletons (pre-std::sync::LazyLock)?
In modern Rust (1.70+), what is the built-in way for lazy singletons?
Is a 'companion object' in Kotlin a Singleton?
o: Yes, it is an object nested in a class

q: Can a Companion Object implement interfaces?
What is the 'Singleton' of the file system?
If you have a 'config.json' file, and 10 classes read it, which pattern avoids reading 10 times?
What is 'memoization'?
o: Caching results of function calls (similar to Singleton holding state)

q: Can a 'Memoized Function' be considered a Singleton?
o: Yes, if it caches a single global result

q: What is 'flyweight' pattern relationship with Singleton?
Which pattern is used to 'manage' Singletons?
Is IoC Container itself a Singleton?
o: Often yes (ApplicationContext), but manages other beans

q: If you subclass Singleton, how do you handle 'getInstance'?
o: Register subclass in a registry or use a factory method to return specific subclass

q: Can you override a static method in Java?
What prevents 'getInstance' from being overridden?
Which pattern allows 'Undo' for Singleton state changes?
If Singleton holds a network connection, what happens on network drop?
o: It must handle reconnection (reconnect logic inside Singleton)

q: What is 'Circuit Breaker' pattern used for in Singleton?
o: Preventing Singleton from overwhelming a failing resource

q: Can 'Circuit Breaker' be a Singleton?
o: Yes, usually state of circuit (Open/Closed) is global/shared

q: Is 'HystrixCommand' a Singleton?
o: No, typically new instance per request

q: Which pattern is used to ensure only one 'Leader' in a cluster?
What if two nodes think they are Singleton Leaders?
Which pattern helps avoid 'Split Brain'?
In a monolithic app, Singleton is scoped to:
In a Microservice, Singleton is scoped to:
If you need a 'Global Singleton' across microservices, use:
Using 'static' in C is different from C++ Singleton because:
o: C doesn't have classes/constructors, but file-scoped static variables effectively act as singletons

q: In TypeScript, 'private constructor' prevents:
Can you use 'getInstance' as a property getter in C#?
Is the 'Clock' object a Singleton?
o: Conceptual Singleton (System Time), usually accessed via static methods

q: Why mock 'Clock' Singleton in tests?
Which pattern replaces 'Clock.now()'?
What is 'Hardcoded Dependency'?
o: Directly calling Singleton.getInstance() inside a method

q: How to break 'Hardcoded Dependency'?
Is 'logger' usually injected or static?
o: Often static final (private), but injection is purer

q: Why is 'static logger' accepted even if it's a hard dependency?
o: Logging is a cross-cutting concern, rarely affects business logic correctness

q: Which pattern is 'java.awt.GraphicsEnvironment'?
What is 'LocalGraphicsEnvironment'?
o: Abstract class, returns platform specific instance

q: Is 'java.lang.Math' a Singleton?
Difference between Singleton and Utility Class?
o: Singleton is an object (can implement interface, pass around), Utility Class is just static methods

q: When to choose Utility Class over Singleton?
o: When you only have static stateless functions (Math.abs)

q: What is 'Effective Java' Item 4?
o: Enforce noninstantiability with a private constructor (for utility classes)

q: Does a private constructor in Utility class prevent reflection?
o: No, but throwing exception inside it does

q: Which pattern is used to 'cache' heavy objects?
Is 'String Pool' in Java a Singleton?
o: The pool itself is a structure managed by JVM (conceptually a singleton resource)

q: Are 'INTERN' strings Singletons?
o: Yes, one instance per unique char sequence

q: Which pattern is used to 'unique' instances?
What is 'Boolean.TRUE' in Java?
o: A static final / Singleton instance of Boolean class

q: Is 'Collections.emptyList()' a Singleton?
o: Yes, returns the same immutable empty list instance

q: Why is 'Collections.emptyList()' Singleton?
o: Optimization (avoids creating new empty list objects)

q: Is 'Optional.empty()' a Singleton?
What implies that 'Optional.empty()' is a Singleton?
Which pattern is used to implement 'Null Object'?
o: Often Singleton (since all nulls are same)

q: Is 'Null Object' always a Singleton?
What is 'The Blob' anti-pattern?
o: A class (often Singleton) that does too much (God Object)

q: How to refactor 'The Blob' Singleton?
o: Split into smaller classes with single responsibilities

q: What is 'Golden Hammer'?
o: Overusing a familiar tool (like using Singleton for everything)

q: Is 'Facade' a Singleton?
o: Often yes, as one facade is enough

q: Is 'State' object a Singleton?
o: State objects are often Singletons if they are stateless

q: Is 'Strategy' object a Singleton?
o: Strategies are often Singletons if they are stateless

q: Can you share a Singleton via RMI?
Does RMI serialize the Singleton?
o: No, passes stub (if Remote), or serialized copy (if Serializable)

q: If RMI passes serialized copy of Singleton, is it still Singleton?
o: No, the client has a copy (unless readResolve tricks are used properly)

q: What is 'JMX' MBean?
o: Java Management Extension Bean (often Singletons managing resources)

q: Are MBeans Singletons?
o: Usually registered as Singletons in MBeanServer

q: Which pattern describes 'MBeanServer'?
Can you use Singleton in Java Applets?
What happens if two Applets use the same Singleton class?
o: If shared ClassLoader, they share instance; if separate, no.

q: Which pattern is used to 'restrict' class instantiation?
Is 'java.lang.Void' a Singleton?
o: It has a static TYPE field, but is not instantiated
